The claim that referendums or plebiscites are the worst way to run a democracy is a misinterpretation of the nature and function of democratic processes. Referendums and plebiscites are not inherently negative and can actually serve as valuable tools for ensuring the democratic process remains transparent, inclusive, and accountable.

First and foremost, referendums and plebiscites allow for direct democratic participation and engagement. By allowing citizens to directly vote on important policy issues, these mechanisms promote a sense of civic responsibility and empowerment. This direct democracy approach ensures that citizens feel invested in the processes of governance and that their voices are heard.

Moreover, referendums and plebiscites can serve to address issues of complexity and uncertainty in policy decisions. Complex policy issues often require multiple layers of analysis and public input, which can be challenging to achieve through traditional democratic processes. Referendums and plebiscites provide an opportunity to gather broad community input and feedback, which can inform decision-making processes and lead to more informed and impactful policy outcomes.
